content:
AUSTRALIA

Gindalbie Metals (GG AT) - Independent expert backs deal for Co. to be acquired by Ansteel. (Newswires)

News Corp (NWS AT) - Seven West Media (SWM AT) will acquire remaining 50.1% share in its Community News JV with News Corp. (SMH)

Santos (STO AT) - Co. JV with Shell was awarded acreage in Queensland. (Newswires)

SpeedCast International (SDA AT) - Co. reportedly could be a target for private equity groups seeking to expand infrastructure funds. (AFR)

Energy - WTI crude futures rose over 1% to above USD 59.00/bbl and Brent crude rose nearly 2% to USD 70.00/bbl. (Newswires)

Other News - NSW gas users have threatened to pull AUD 2bln in planned investment from the state over delays. (The Australian)

 

JAPAN

Sharp (6753 JT) - Co. plans to move production of laptops away from China to avoid US tariffs. (Newswires)

Tokyo Electron (8035 JT) - Co. will repurchase JPY 150bln in shares or 8.5% of total outstanding. (Newswires)

Other News - Japan’s government announces new rule to limit foreign ownership in IT and telecom firms effective from August. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

CJ CheilJedang (097950 KS) - Co. is said to be in advanced discussions regarding potential sale of animal feed assets which could be valued at USD 1.7bln. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission Chief said escalation of US-China trade disputes have had a limited impact on China's financial markets and that China has not taken any deliberate measures to devalue the CNY. Furthermore, the CBIRC Chief commented that financial risks are controllable and CNY bears will suffer. (Newswires)

Global Times opinion piece rhetorically asks “What on earth does the US want with China? Does it want fair trade or does the US refuse to accept China's development and seek to break the Chinese economy as its ultimate goal?”. Furthermore, the article alleges that Washington rudely tries to use a tariff war to suppress China and suggested the Chinese will not yield if Washington turns its jealousy against China's development into all-round containment of the country. (Global Times)

 

UK/EU

ECB's Hansson said ECB should be less generous in pricing the TLTROs and that a less generous loan should signal policy normalisation, while he added that tiering ECB rates would risk overcomplicating ECB policy. (Newswires)

EU commission mulls opening disciplinary process against Italy over rising debt levels potentially as soon as June 5th, while reports added that Italy risks up to EUR 4bln EU penalty. (Newswires)

Austrian Chancellor Kurz was ousted after losing a no confidence vote. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Russian Energy Minister Novak hopes OPEC and partners will be able to formalise the OPEC+ agreement by June with the adoption of a new charter. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

US and UK markets were closed.

subject: (EARLY) US MARKET WRAP - 27 May 2019: Markets thin as US, UK away; European Elections see little major impact
content:
* SNAPSHOT: US Equity futures flat, US Treasuries futures higher, Dollar up, Crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Trump says US not ready for trade deal with China, EC might penalise Italy over debt, EU elections digested uneventfully

* THIS WEEK: TUE: Hungary rate decision. WED: BOC rate decision, German Jobs Report, Richmond Fed. THU: Aussie Building Approvals, CAPEX; NZ Budget; US GDP, Pending Home Sales. FRI: Japanese jobs data, Tokyo CPI, industrial output; BOK rate decision; German retail sales, CPI; US personal spending, core PCE, Michigan; Canadian GDP. Click here for Week in Focus.

CENTRAL BANK WEEKLY: Previewing BOC, BOK; Reviewing FOMC, ECB, RBA, SARB, CBRT. Click here for Central Bank Weekly.

* TRADE: President Trump said the US is "not ready" to make a trade deal with China, though China would like to make a deal. Trump also threatened that tariffs on Chinese goods could go up "very easily." The comments were made on his State Visit to Japan. However, the President suggested that he believes that a trade deal could be reached sometime in the future, and that China and the US will absolutely have a great trade deal.

* ITALY: EU commission is considering opening the disciplinary process on Italy, perhaps as soon as 5 June, over 2018 debt levels, and Italy risks up to EUR 4bln EU fine. The News added to the Bund/BTP widening seen on Monday.

* AUSTRIA: Chancellor Kurz has been ousted after losing a confidence following the “Ibiza affair” scandal that split his coalition apart. President Van Der Bellen is now expected to place a technocratic government in charge until elections in Q3.

* EU ELECTIONS: There wasn’t anything to scare the markets in the outcome of the European Elections. Turnout across the bloc was decent, and greens, nationalists and liberals performed well.; the right wing anti-EU parties extended their share of the vote to 23% (vs. 20% in 2014), and meanwhile, the four largest pro-European parties saw their combined share of the vote fall to 67% from 70%, still leaving a majority of pro-Europeans in the Parliament. Click here for the full RANsquawk analysis of the EU Elections.

* ECB: ECB’s Hansson said that any new TLTRO facility should be priced with less-generous terms, signalling that the central bank is on track for normalisation, adding that tiering ECB rates would risk overcomplicating policy, and may unfairly help the banking sector more than others.

* GEOPOLITICS: The North Koreans said US National Security advisor Bolton was incorrect in concluding that recent missile tests were a violation of UN resolutions. US President Trump is expecting “good things” on North Korea, noting that there had not been any nuclear testing. Trump said he was in no rush with North Korea, and that he was not bothered by the recent launch of short-range missiles. On Iran, Trump again stated that he was not seeking regime change; the Iranians later said US sanctions policy has threatened stability in the Middle East. 

* THIS WEEK'S TREASURY SUPPLY: The US Treasury will auction a total of USD 131bln in new 2-year (USD 40bln, Tue), new 5-year (USD 41bln, also on Tue), and new 7-year (USD 32bln, Wed), as well as a 2-year FRN re-opening (USD 18bln, Wed). UBS notes that there are USD 81bln of cash flows this week (including USD 73bln of redemptions + USD 8bln of coupons) falling due, implying net supply at around USD 50bln. Recent Auctions have generally been received well, TD Securities notes, even though recent 10-year sale was soft. TD notes that takedown statistics show investment funds continuing to take increasing allotments in recent months (54% of April supply). "Despite Treasury's decision not to cut coupon auction sizes later this year, we believe the Fed's open market purchases of Treasuries to replace MBS runoff later this year will help buoy the market," TD says. Recent auctions suggests the 2-year auction could stop on the screws with a 64% buy-side takedown (48% indirect, 16% direct); after last month's solid demand at the 5-year auction, recent averages point to a small tail (0.2bps), with 74% buy-side takedown).

* CRUDE: The crude complex reopened Sunday evening on the back foot, trading choppy through the European session amid light trade and narrow ranges, with the US and UK players away due to market holidays. The complex caught a bid in afternoon trade, but Action seems capped at USD 70 for Brent and USD 59 for WTI. In terms of a narrative, there has been little updates on energy markets with newswires highlighting the over-arching themes currently in energy markets. Analysts note that limiting gains on the upside is the pessimistic global demand outlook, with a lack of resolution on the US-China trade front feeding into that. To take the side of the bulls, the geopolitical risk premium associated with an increasing US presence in the Persian Gulf will be providing some tail winds; separately supporting prices, OPEC+ production cuts are not likely to abruptly end anytime too soon where, excluding Russia, OPEC+ members last weekend expressed support for sustained cuts.

* FOREX: USD has not seen any of the choppiness that we have come to expect (consolidating around 97.75), after Trump said US is not ready to make a trade deal with China, although US participants are away for Memorial Day. Havens JPY, CHF were slightly lower (JPY back to 109.50, CHF above parity). EUR saw some downside in the European day (slightly sub-1.12), pressured by widening Bund/BTP yield differentials, after reports the EC might open up proceedings on Italy over high debt; the European Elections had only a modest impact on financial markets. GBP is softer (sub 1.27) as Brexit Party took the largest share at the European Elections in the UK, reinforcing the impression that the Tories will need to come out strongly in favour of Brexit if they are to avoid losing further vote share. CAD trades neutral (c. 1.3440) ahead of Wednesday’s BOC, where the bank is likely to reiterate the need for accommodation despite improving domestic fundamentals. AUD (thin range above 0.69) and NZD (thin range around 0.6950) flat/slightly lower. CNH slightly stronger vs USD after CBIRC on the weekend said it did not expect a persistent decline in Yuan, and warned speculative shorts they would suffer "heavy losses" if they bet against the yuan. Other EMFX is mixed.

subject: Russian Energy Minister Novak hopes OPEC and partners will be able to formalise the OPEC+ agreement by June, with the adoption of a new charter
content: Novak says "the draft, in principle, has been prepared for a long time, now it is being approved. The OPEC coordinated. The OPEC secretariat is working out the details; they are working with the countries. I hope that it will be agreed upon by the June meeting."

Daily FX Wrap: thin trade amid UK/US holiday closures post European elections
content:
USD

The Buck has gained traction in recent trade amid thin liquidity and a lack of catalysts due to UK and US traders enjoying a long weekend. The Greenback was little fazed by comments from US President Trump at the US-Japan presser in which he noted that the US is not ready for a trade deal with China yet. The Dollar index has picked up some steam recently, albeit remaining within a 97.55-85.

EUR

Throughout the morning, the single currency ranged just beneath 1.1200 (vs USD) in the aftermath of uneventful European Parliamentary elections. In afternoon trade, EURUSD saw a small pop lower to 1.1190 on news that the European Commission was mulling disciplinary action against Italy over its growing debt levels, with the potential fine being up to EUR 4bln. Bund-BTP spreads widened on the news. Returning to issue of Parliamentary Elections; focus will now be set on a coalition building process and the follow-through from the nomination of a European Commission President (following Juncker’s departure on October 31st) to the ECB President (EC and ECB Presidents are unlikely be from the same country). In terms of potential coalitions, the main scenarios are touted, with 376 seats needed for majority: 1) EPP, Socialists, Liberals, Greens (506 seats), 2) EPP, Socialists, Liberals (436 seats), 3) EPP, Socialists, Green (399 seats). Nonetheless, EUR/USD fluctuates on either side of 1.1200 and within a relatively narrow 1.1190-1215 band with just over 600mln in option expiries scattered between strike 1.1175-1200.

GBP

On the other side of channel, the Pound drifted lower, with some traders attributing downside in Cable to a slight pickup in the Dollar. However, an uncertain political backdrop regarding Brexit remains; in which some are suggesting the Brexit party’s recent advances in the European elections may spur potential successors to UK PM May to take a harder line on Europe.

CHF, JPY

The “risk-on” mood coupled with the thin liquidity has sparked an unwind in risk premium with both currencies underperforming in the G10 space and losing vs the USD and EUR. EUR/CHF did see some downside on news that the European Commission may discipline Italy, but remains in the middle of its intraday range of 1.1220-63 whilst USD/JPY tests resistance at the 109.50 level.

AUD, CAD, NZD

Again, little movement in the currencies due to a lack of catalysts and Europe’s largest FX trading hub away on Bank Holiday. The risk currencies seem to take the cue from the Dollar for now with all three pairs vs. Buck trading within a 20 pip intraday range.

EM

The Turkish Lira remains in the spotlight amid the CBRT’s continuing attempts to stem its depreciation. Latest efforts involve hiking the RRR for FX deposits by 200bps to withdraw liquidity USD 4.2bln in liquidity from the market. The move seeped some strength into the TRY with USD/TRY now around 6.0500 having fluctuated within a 6.0350-1000 range thus far.

subject: BCB forecasts FDI inflows of USD 7.5bln in May
Analysis: EU Parliamentary Elections
content:
SUMMARY: European elections failed to deliver any drastic upsets; right wing anti-EU parties extended their share of the vote to 23% (vs. 20% in 2014). The Greens & Liberals also put in a strong showing, especially in France, Germany and the UK. In sum, the four largest pro-European parties saw their combined share of the vote fall to 67% from 70%.

PARLIAMENTARY ARITHMETIC: The current two largest pro-European and centrist parties, the EPP and S&D are expected to lose their majority, their total seat count falling to 320. The biggest gainers were the liberals/greens and right-wing/nationalist parties. CapEco notes “if the EPP and S&D team up with the centrist Alliance of Liberals and Democrats (ALDE), which is projected to win just over 100 seats, they will have a clear majority.” For this reason, it expects pro-European policies proposed by the European Council and Commission to continue to receive parliamentary approval and, as such, EU economic policy to continue unaffected, adding “it makes sense that there has been little or no reaction in currency or bond markets so far” (albeit there has been a slight widening of BTP-Bund spreads, and a narrowing of Greek/Germany differentials after the pro-business party performed well and PM Tsipras called elections).

KEY JOBS - EC PRESIDENT: EU leaders will now look to determine who gets the top jobs at two summits; the first this Tuesday, the second on 20-21 June. Manfred Weber of the centre right EPP, who remain the largest party in the parliament, is expected to maintain his claim to precede current head of the European Commission Junker. However, SocGen notes a progressive alliance comprising Greens, Socialists and possibly liberals from the ALDE means EC VP Timmermans or Competition Commissioner Vestager could also be in the running.

KEY JOBS - ECB PRESIDENT: On a possible successor for Draghi as ECB President, Berenberg suggests that “if Weber still manages to succeed Jean-Claude Juncker at the helm of the European Commission, France would probably nominate Francois Villeroy de Galhau (or [Bank of France deputy] Sylvie Goulard) as the next ECB president” whilst, if Weber’s bid fails, “Germany may claim the ECB for Jens Weidmann, with Finland’s Olli Rehn as a potential compromise candidate acceptable to virtually all euro member governments”. Italy may ask for a consolation prize, Berenberg suggests, which could be a foreign policy chief acceptable to Salvini.

GERMANY: German Chancellor Merkel’s coalition suffered their worst ever result in a national election; CDU/CSU and SPD support fell to below 29% and 16% respectively. Support for the Greens grew to 20%, while AfD garnered 11% of the vote. Berenberg notes that the collapse in support for SPD increases risk that left wingers in the party may force a walkout of the party’s current coalition with Merkel’s CDU/CSU, a move which would bring down the current German Chancellor. However, Berenberg considers it more likely they will postpone any decision to after state elections in East Germany and their mid-term review of the coalition with CDU/CSU.

FRANCE: French President Macron’s party just lost out to Le Pen’s right-wing party, with 22.3% and 23.4% respectively, however support for the latter fell from 24.9% in 2014. Berenberg notes that with Macron’s solid majority in French parliament, he still has plenty of time for his reforms to work before elections in 2022.

ITALY: Salvini’s right wing Lega party garnered the most support with 34.3%, his governing coalition party Five Star Movement got 17%. CapEco suggests that Salvini’s strong showing may encourage him to end the current coalition with Five Star and either call an election or join forces with Berlusconi’s Forza Italia. The consultancy notes “Italian economic policy should not change much: a coalition between the League and Forza Italia would be equally likely to clash with the EU.”

UK: As expected, the Brexit party won the highest vote share with 31.6%, a result that Berenberg suggest is likely to encourage the Conservative Party leadership contenders to take a harder line on Europe. However, Berenberg also notes that support for hard-line Brexit parties (Brexit party + UKIP) has only increased 7.5% since 2014, whilst the two major parties shed 26.1% since 2014. In that regard, the major winner is the Liberal Democrats, who gained 20% of the vote (up from 7% in 2014).

GREECE: Greek PM Tsipras’s Syriza party (23.7%) were defeated by the centre-right Mitsotakis’s New Democracy party (33.2%), spurring Tspiras to call an early general election, in which the New Democracy party are expected to win. Berenberg comment that “the centre-right would probably safeguard the key achievements of Greece’s harsh adjustment programme and raise trend growth through tax reform and deregulation.”

Fixed Income Update: Muted trade on Memorial Day
content:
In fitting with the tone of the day, little conviction is being seen in EU debt trading, with most benchmarks extending on the aforementioned rangy trade. 10yr German fixed income futures have built on their upside, with the top side capped by 167.50, spurring 10yr yields to print a new 2019 low of -13.3bps. Combining this with the League-spurred downside being seen in BTP futures (fresh session lows of 130.65) has seen the BTP-Bund spread break 270 bps, with Italian debt traders eyeing the May 17th high next up on the downside (130.21).

Moving stateside, fixed income futures have seen little to trade off of on Memorial Day besides the remnants of some negative trade comments from the President. As such, we are essentially in the same place we were at the start of the day, with the majority of the (lacklustre) action being seen in the belly of the curve. As such traders will now be looking ahead to supply tomorrow in the form of USD 40bln and USD 41bln up for grabs at the 2yr and 5yr note auctions after US Consumer Confidence.

RANsquawk EU Mid Session: All quiet on the Western front amid mass closures - 27th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

European equities trade on the front-foot [Eurostoxx 50 +0.4%] following on from a mixed lead in Asia amid the absence of UK and US participants. Sectors are all higher with industrial names lagging due to dismal Chinese industrial profits data overnight, whilst on the flip side, the consumer discretionary sector is driven forward by the mass gains in auto names sparked by a 50/50 merger agreement between Fiat Chrysler (+10.0%) and Renault (+13.7%). The merged entity will reportedly take over a year to set-up, with sources stating that Renault will delay its merger plans with Nissan if an agreement is struck with Fiat Chrysler. The news, coupled with a seemingly positive meeting between US and Japan underpinned the likes of Daimler (+0.8%), Volkswagen (+0.7%), BMW (+0.5%) in sympathy. However, Peugeot shares (-2.8%) failed to benefit from the FCA/Renault announcement amid competition in the French auto market alongside prior speculation of a potential Fiat-Peugeot tie-up. Furthermore, Exor (+6%) also spiked higher at the open given its 29% ownership in Fiat Chrysler. In terms of other movers, SMI giant Novartis (+1.6%) opened higher after receiving two FDA approvals, with one being for the world’s most expensive drug.

FX

USD - The Buck has gained traction in recent trade amid thin liquidity and a lack of catalysts due to UK and US traders enjoying a long weekend. The Buck was little fazed by comments from US President Trump at the US-Japan presser in which he noted that the US is not ready for a trade deal with China yet. The Dollar index has picked up some steam recently, albeit remains within a 97.55-73 range with only potential macro newsflow to eye throughout the day.

GBP, EUR - The single currency is little changed as the dust settles from the European Parliamentary elections in which prelim results indicated a shrinking in the centrist parties which have fallen short of the majority needed in the 751-strong assembly. Eyes will now be set on a coalition building process and the follow-through from the nomination of a European Commission President (following Juncker’s departure on October 31st) to the ECB President (EC and ECB Presidents are unlikely be from the same country). In terms of potential coalitions, the main scenarios are touted, with 376 seats needed for majority: 1) EPP, Socialists, Liberals, Greens (506 seats), 2) EPP, Socialists, Liberals (436 seats), 3) EPP, Socialists, Green (399 seats). Nonetheless, EUR/USD fluctuates on either side of 1.1200 and within a relatively narrow 1.1190-1215 band with just over 600mln in option expiries scattered between strike 1.1175-1200. Over on the other side of channel, the Pound also trades with flat on the day, albeit off highs and closer to the bottom of a 1.2700-55 range vs. the Greenback with recent downside in Cable attributed to a slight pickup in the Dollar

CHF, JPY - The “risk-on” mood coupled with the thin liquidity has sparked an unwind in risk premium with both currencies underperforming in the G10 space and losing vs the USD and EUR. EUR/CHF currently remains near the top of the currency intraday range of 1.1220-63 whilst USD/JPY tests support at the 109.50 level.

AUD, CAD, NZD - Again, little movement in the currencies due to a lack of catalysts and Europe’s largest FX trading hub away on Bank Holiday. The risk currencies seem to take the cue from the Dollar for now with all three pairs vs. Buck trading within a 20 pip intraday range.

EM - The Turkish Lira remains in the spotlight amid the CBRT’s continuing attempts to stem its depreciation. Latest effort involve hiking the RRR for FX deposits by 200bps to withdraw liquidity USD 4.2bln in liquidity from the market. The move seeped some strength into the TRY with USD/TRY now around 6.0500 having fluctuated within a 6.0350-1000 range thus far.

FIXED INCOME

Core EU debt trading has largely been driven by the European Parliamentary results, which saw the centre-right lose ground to the effervescent Greens and the growing left and right-wing parties. 10yr Bund futures are outperforming and trade ~17-ticks higher of Friday’s close and sit comfortably at the top of a 20-tick range. The main takeaway from the mainland elections comes from Italy, however, which saw League gain ground and develop a vociferous lead over their coalition partners with this sparking more concerns over the stability of their agreement. 10yr BTP futures trade with losses of about 10 ticks and remain the loss leader in Europe, as the benchmark hangs below the 131.00 level with the May 17th 130.31 high eyed up next on the downside.

US debt trading has been dampened by the Memorial Day holiday, with futures largely unchanged across the curve despite some more negative vibes being eschewed by the President on US-China trade. With little to look forward to for the day ahead besides cursory US-Sino comments, alongside closed pit trading and an early electronic trade close of 6pm, trade has been light thus far, with investors likely looking forward to Tuesday’s US Consumer Confidence release.

COMMODITIES

WTI (-0.5%) and Brent (+0.1%) are mixed with the former subdued amid fears of a supply glut in the US, whilst the latter is supported amid rising political tensions in the Middle East. Furthermore, the Brent/WTI spread has also widened to USD 10.40/bbl vs. USD 9.55/bbl at the front-end of last week. News flows has been light for the complex thus far, with traders keeping an eye on Dollar action and macro developments to influence energy prices. Elsewhere, Gold (+0.1%) is little changed having moved in a USD 4/oz range thus far amid little news, while in terms of tech levels, the yellow metal’s 50 DMA stands at USD 1288.57/oz and 21 DMA at USD 1282.88/oz. Looking at base metals, copper continues its rebound from near-YTD lows amid the risk-appetite in the market, whilst Dalian iron ore surged in excess of 5% to hit new highs since 2013 as port stocks continue to drop alongside renewed fears of a potential dam collapse in Brazil. Iron ore at Chinese ports shrunk to the lowest in over to years according to SteelHome data, whilst Vale’s recent warnings about a potential dam collapse Minas Gerais also bolstered steel prices.

subject: Renault (RNO FP) state that they are closely examining the terms of the Fiat (FCA IM) deal
analysis_details: • Recap: Fiat Chrysler has submitted the proposal for a transformative merger with Renault wherein both companies will own 50% of the group each with balanced governance structure and majority of the board of directors being independent. FCA says there will be no plant closures as a results of the merger. Co. sees in excess of EUR 5bln estimated annual run rate synergies incremental to the existing Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi alliance. FCA says the merger would have a strong balance sheet. Renault confirmed the receipt of a proposal from FCA regarding a 50/50 merger transaction. (Newswires) Over the weekend. sources stated that the deal could involve an initial exchange in equity. Renault’s existing alliance partners, Nissan (7201 JT) and Mitsubishi (7211 JT) will not be involved but may be invited to join at a later time, according to the sources. Furthermore, Renault has reportedly agreed to delay any plans to merge with Nissan in the short-term if an agreement with Fiat Chrysler was reached. (FT/CNBC/Newswires)

subject: FX Morning Colour: Creeping Buck keeps G10 peers off highs, Lira inspired by RRR hike
content:
USD

The Buck has gained traction in recent trade amid thin liquidity and a lack of catalysts due to UK and US traders enjoying a long weekend. The Buck was little fazed by comments from US President Trump at the US-Japan presser in which he noted that the US is not ready for a trade deal with China yet. The Dollar index has picked up some steam recently, albeit remains within a 97.55-70 range with only potential macro newsflow to eye throughout the day.

GBP, EUR

The single currency is little changed as the dust settles from the European Parliamentary elections in which prelim results indicated a shrinking in the centrist parties which have fallen short of the majority needed in the 751-strong assembly. Eyes will now be set on a coalition building process and the follow-through from the nomination of a European Commission President (following Juncker’s departure on October 31st) to the ECB President (EC and ECB Presidents are unlikely be from the same country). In terms of potential coalitions, the main scenarios are touted, with 376 seats needed for majority: 1) EPP, Socialists, Liberals, Greens (506 seats), 2) EPP, Socialists, Liberals (436 seats), 3) EPP, Socialists, Green (399 seats). Nonetheless, EUR/USD fluctuates on either side of 1.1200 and within a relatively narrow 1.1190-1215 band with just over 600mln in option expiries scattered between strike 1.1175-1200. Over on the other side of channel, the Pound also trades with flat on the day, albeit off highs and closer to the bottom of a 1.2715-55 range vs. the Greenback with recent downside in Cable attributed to a slight pickup in the Dollar

CHF, JPY

The “risk-on” mood coupled with the thin liquidity has sparked an unwind in risk premium with both currencies underperforming in the G10 space and losing vs the USD and EUR. EUR/CHF currently remains near the top of the currency intraday range of 1.1220-56 whilst USD/JPY found some support at the 109.50 level. 

AUD, CAD, NZD

Again, little movement in the currencies due to a lack of catalysts and Europe’s largest FX trading hub away on Bank Holiday. The risk currencies seem to take the cue from the Dollar for now with all three pairs vs. Buck trading within a 20 pip intraday range.

EM

The Turkish Lira remains in the spotlight amid the CBRT’s continuing attempts to stem its depreciation. Latest effort involve hiking the RRR for FX deposits by 200bps to withdraw liquidity USD 4.2bln in liquidity from the market. The move seeped some strength into the TRY with USD/TRY now around 6.0500 having fluctuated within a 6.0350-1000 range thus far.

content:
Core EU debt trading has largely been driven by the European Parliamentary results, which saw the centre-right lose ground to the effervescent Greens and the growing left and right-wing parties. 10yr Bund futures are outperforming and trade ~15-ticks higher of Friday’s close and sit comfortably at the top of a 20-tick range. The main takeaway from the mainland elections comes from Italy, however, which saw League gain ground and develop a vociferous lead over their coalition partners with this sparking more concerns over the stability of their agreement. 10yr BTP futures trade with losses of about 10 ticks and remain the loss leader in Europe, as the benchmark hangs around the 131.00 level with the May 17th 130.31 high eyed up next on the downside.

US debt trading has been dampened by the Memorial Day holiday, with futures largely unchanged across the curve despite some more negative vibes being eschewed by the President on US-China trade. With little to look forward to for the day ahead besides cursory US-Sino comments, alongside closed pit trading and an early electronic trade close of 6pm, trade has been light thus far, with investors likely looking forward to Tuesday’s US Consumer Confidence release.

subject: Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) says the new entity with Renault (RNO FP) could take up over a year to set up, according to reports
analysis_details:
• This comes as Fiat Chrysler submitted the proposal for a transformative merger with Renault wherein both companies will own 50% of the group each with balanced governance structure and majority of the board of directors being independent. 
  • FCA says there will be no plant closures as a results of the merger. Co. sees in excess of EUR 5bln estimated annual run rate synergies incremental to the existing Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi alliance. FCA says the merger would have a strong balance sheet. 
  • Renault confirmed the receipt of a proposal from FCA regarding a 50/50 merger transaction.  
  • Over the weekend. sources stated that the deal could involve an initial exchange in equity. Renault’s existing alliance partners, Nissan (7201 JT) and Mitsubishi (7211 JT) will not be involved but may be invited to join at a later time, according to the sources. Furthermore, Renault has reportedly agreed to delay any plans to merge with Nissan in the short-term if an agreement with Fiat Chrysler was reached. (FT/CNBC/Newswires)

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

27th May 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

**NOTE: UK AND CASH MARKETS AND EQUITY FUTURES WILL BE CLOSED TODAY DUE TO SPRING BANK HOLIDAY **

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week mixed as a lack of risk drivers and an extended weekend in some major global markets resulted to a non-committal tone in the region. ASX 200 (-0.1%) was indecisive with strength in mining names offset by losses in financials. Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) was positive but with price action contained by recent currency moves and after President Trump suggested a US-Japan trade deal can wait until after the Japanese upper house elections in July. Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) were subdued following weak Industrial Profits data which declined by 3.7%, although some of the losses were later pared as the stats bureau attributed the decline in profits to a rush increase in production prior to a VAT cut as well as a high 2018 base, while the PBoC also injected CNY 80bln of liquidity via reverse repos.

FTSE

ITV (ITV LN) – Sources stated that negotiations between the Co. and BBC have grown tense amid a face-off over their joint streaming service Britbox, which was seen to rival Netflix. Sources added that ITV committed more fully to the subscription service than BBC. (FT)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Thomas Cook (TCG LN) – Co. are attempting to please investors with a new plan to transform itself into a holiday market place, which will see the Co. focus on its website, but it will continue to own hotels which will be kept off the balance sheet via a “hotel fund”. City source noted that many investors are buoyed at the Co’s plans. (Telegraph)

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co’s top investment banker Garth Ritchie could quit amid disagreements over cuts and lack of support from shareholders, according to senior figures. (FT)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – SK Innovation (096770 KS) noted that the Cos are still in talks over a battery-making JV. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Uniper (UN01 GY) – Co’s chairman said talks with shareholder Fortum (FORTUM FH) to resolve a dispute are on hold after Uniper board members resigned. Furthermore, Uniper COO and Chief Commercial Officer are to terminate board mandates and employment contracts effective 30th November. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

LVMH (MC FP) – Co. has reportedly been subpoenaed by a federal grand jury in regard to the probe of US media buying practices. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM)/ Renault (RNO FP) – Fiat Chrysler has submitted the proposal for a transformative merger with Renault wherein both companies will own 50% of the group each with balanced governance structure and majority of the board of directors being independent. FCA says there will be no plant closures as a results of the merger. Co. sees in excess of EUR 5bln estimated annual run rate synergies incremental to the existing Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi alliance. FCA says the merger would have a strong balance sheet. Renault confirmed the receipt of a proposal from FCA regarding a 50/50 merger transaction. (Newswires) Over the weekend. sources stated that the deal could involve an initial exchange in equity. Renault’s existing alliance partners, Nissan (7201 JT) and Mitsubishi (7211 JT) will not be involved but may be invited to join at a later time, according to the sources. Furthermore, Renault has reportedly agreed to delay any plans to merge with Nissan in the short-term if an agreement with Fiat Chrysler was reached. (FT/CNBC/Newswires)

SMI

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA 

BROKER MOVES

US

BROKER MOVES

* S&P 500 0.2% at 2827, Dow Jones 0.4% at 25594, NASDAQ-100 -0.1% at 7301; SECTORS: S&P 500 Consumer Discretionary  0.2%, S&P 500 Consumer Staples  -0.4%, S&P 500 Energy  0.2%, S&P 500 Financials  0.8%, S&P 500 Health Care  0.2%, S&P 500 Industrials  0.1%, S&P 500 Information Technology  0.1%, S&P 500 Materials  0.5%, S&P 500 Telecommunication Services  0%, S&P 500 Utilities  -0.2%

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 27th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets began the week mixed as a lack of risk drivers and an extended weekend in some major global markets resulted to a non-committal tone in the region
  • Preliminary results from the European Parliament elections indicate the centre-right and centre-left groups are set to remain the biggest groups but have fallen short of a majority
  • President Trump suggested a US-Japan trade deal can wait until after the Japanese upper house elections in July
  • Looking ahead, today’s calendar sees a lack of tier 1 highlights; UK and US markets are closed

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week mixed as a lack of risk drivers and an extended weekend in some major global markets resulted to a non-committal tone in the region. ASX 200 (-0.1%) was indecisive with strength in mining names offset by losses in financials. Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) was positive but with price action contained by recent currency moves and after President Trump suggested a US-Japan trade deal can wait until after the Japanese upper house elections in July. Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) were subdued following weak Industrial Profits data which declined by 3.7%, although some of the losses were later pared as the stats bureau attributed the decline in profits to a rush increase in production prior to a VAT cut as well as a high 2018 base, while the PBoC also injected CNY 80bln of liquidity via reverse repos. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat as they mirrored the recent sideways price action in T-notes and with the BoJ presence in the market for JPY 1tln of JGBs counterbalanced by the lack of safe-haven demand in Japan.

PBoC injected CNY 80bln via 7-day reverse repo. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8924 (Prev. 6.8993)

Chinese Industrial Profits (Apr) Y/Y -3.7% (Prev. 13.9%). (Newswires)

China MOF plans to restrict direct investment from foreign IT companies beginning in August. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor expects US-China trade deal will be reached but stated there are currently factors complicating a resolution. (Twitter)

US President Trump said US and Japan are nearing a big trade announcement but also noted that they can wait until after the Japanese elections for a trade deal with Japan, which indicates an agreement may not happen during his visit this week. (Nikkei)

UK/EU

Preliminary results from the European Parliament elections indicated the centre-right and centre-left groups are set to remain the biggest groups but have fallen short of the majority needed in the 751-strong assembly for the 1st time since the 1970 with the European People’s Party projected to win 179 seats (Prev. 217 seats) and Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats projected to win 150 seats (Prev. 189). Meanwhile, Liberals, Eurosceptic and Green parties are projected to gain ground which reportedly could complicate coalition talks. (Newswires/WSJ)

On a national basis, the UK vote share showed Brexit Party are to win 28 seats with 33% of votes, Lib Dems at 15 seats with 21%, Labour at 10 seats with 15%, Green at 7 seats with 13% and Conservative at 3 seats with 9%. However, the results also showed ‘Remain’ parties had 40% of support vs. 35% of support for the ‘Pro-Brexit’ parties. (Newswires) Elsewhere, France’s National Rally Party (23.5%) defeated President Macron’s Renaissance Party (22.5%), albeit with a smaller than anticipated margin of victory. In Germany, Chancellor Merkel’s CDU Party (28%) was the clear winner with the SPD’s (15.6%) share of the vole collapsing. The Italian vote, Salvini’s League Party won 33.6% if the vote with the 5SM (16.7%) Party falling behind the Democratic Party (23.5%); Deputy PM Salvini said nothing should change at the national level following the EU vote. Elsewhere, Greek Prime Minister Tsipras said he cannot ignore election results and has called for snap elections following a heavy defeat by his Syriza party at European Parliament elections which trails behind opposition New Democracy by around 9 points. (Newswires) Please click here for a more detailed breakdown of the vote

Boris Johnson and Dominic Raab have been warned that Tory MPs would be prepared to bring down any prime minister backing a no-deal Brexit, triggering a general election. (Guardian) Elsewhere, over the weekend Michael Gove and Matt Hancock joined the race to become the next UK PM. (CityAM) The latest list of candidates is as follows: Johnson, Raab, Gove, Hancock, Hunt, Stewart, McVey, Leadsom. (City AM) UK Brexit Party leader Farage said he will work with Boris Johnson or anyone if it meant delivering on Brexit. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Portugal at BBB; Outlook revised to Positive. (Newswires)

FX

 

The DXY was subdued around the 97.50 level following last week’s softness and retreat from 98.00, while the holiday closure in the US for Memorial Day added to the lacklustre trade. The greenback’s major counterparts held on to recent gains with EUR/USD above 1.1200 despite the European Parliament Election results which showed the centrist parties remained by far the dominant force in Europe but failed to achieve a majority for the first time since the 1970s as liberals, greens and Eurosceptics gained some ground, which therefore shifts focus on coalition building. Nonetheless, this failed to dent EUR/USD given the unlikelihood for any major fallout across the national level aside from Greece where PM Tsipras called for a snap election after his party trailed the main opposition by as much as 9 points. GBP/USD stabilized after last Friday’s swings through peaks and troughs triggered by PM May’s resignation announcement, with the UK also closed for holiday and participants awaiting who will emerge the victor in a crowded race to be PM May’s successor. Elsewhere, USD/JPY attempted to nurse losses and eyed 109.50, while antipodeans were flat around last week’s highs amid the mixed risk tone and weak greenback.

 

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were mixed with WTI crude futures subdued as it retreated further away from resistance at the USD 59.00/bbl which also follows the recent slump in which trade related fears and bearish inventory data spurred a 9% drop last week. Elsewhere, gold held near the prior day’s best levels as a weaker greenback provided a platform for the precious metal, while copper also saw mild gains as sentiment in mainland China gradually improved and amid strength in Dalian iron ore futures which surged over 5% shortly after the open due to ongoing supply concerns.

Baker Hughes (May 24) US oil rigs -5 at 797, US nat gas rigs +1 at 186, total US rigs -4 at 983. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump approved sending 1,500 troops to the Middle East which he stated was for "mostly protective" reasons. In related news, US military said that intelligence suggests a "campaign" by Iran that ties together threats across the region, while it also alleged Iranian Revolutionary Guards are directly responsible for attacks on tankers outside the UAE. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he thinks good things will come with North Korea and that there has not been nuclear or rocket testing, although he added he could be wrong on North Korea. (Newswires)

North Korea said US National Security Adviser Bolton is wrong to conclude missile test was in violation of UN resolutions, while it added that giving up missile launches would mean giving up right to self-defence. (KCNA)

US

Treasury trade was lacklustre and sideways ahead of the long weekend; the bias was for higher yields with the US Treasury curve bear-flattening. In early trade, the dip was attributed to profit taking, and in European trade, the complex took its cue from the Gilt, after UK PM May announced a timeline for her departure. After Europeans left, sideways trade resumed, with Thursday's ranges largely remaining intact. Major curve spreads tightened at settlement. US T-Note futures (M9) settled 10 ticks lower at 124-28+.

US President Trump reiterated his view that US growth would have exceeded 3% if the Fed did not raise rates last year. (Newswires)

(+0.3%) were subdued following weak Industrial Profits data which declined by 3.7%, although some of the losses were later pared as the stats bureau attributed the decline in profits to a rush increase in production prior to a VAT cut as well as a high 2018 base, while the PBoC also injected CNY 80bln of liquidity via reverse repos. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat as they mirrored the recent sideways price action in T-notes and with the BoJ presence in the market for JPY 1tln of JGBs counterbalanced by the lack of safe-haven demand in Japan.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia begins the week indecisive amid a lack of risk catalysts and key global market closures
content:
Asia equity markets begin the week mixed as a lack of risk drivers and an extended weekend in some major global markets results to a non-committal tone in the region. ASX 200 (Unch.) is indecisive with strength in mining names offset by losses in financials although Vocus shares have surged around 20% after the telco was approached by EQT Infrastructure for AUD 5.25/Shr which is around 35% premium to Friday’s close. Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) is positive but with price action contained by a choppy currency and after President Trump suggested a US-Japan trade deal can wait until after the Japanese upper house elections in July. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) are subdued following weak Industrial Profits data which declined by 3.7%, although losses are contained as the stats bureau cited a rush increase in production prior to VAT cut and high 2018 base for the decline in profits, while the PBoC also injected CNY 80bln of liquidity via reverse repos.

In FX markets, the DXY is subdued around the 97.50 level following last week’s softness for USD and retreat from 98.00, while the holiday closure in the US for Memorial Day adds to the lacklustre trade. The greenback’s major counterparts hold on to recent gains with EUR/USD above 1.1200 despite the European Parliament Election results which showed the centrist parties remained by far the dominant force in Europe although have failed to achieve a majority for the first time since the 1970s as liberals, greens and Eurosceptics gained some ground which therefore shifts focus on coalition building. Nonetheless, this failed to dent EUR/USD given the unlikelihood for any major fallout across the national level aside from Greece where PM Tsipras called for a snap election after his party trailed the main opposition by as much as 9 points. Elsewhere, GBP/USD has stabilized after last Friday’s swings through peaks and troughs triggered by PM May’s resignation announcement, with the UK also closed for holiday and participants awaiting who will emerge the victor in a crowded race to be PM May’s successor. Elsewhere, USD/JPY attempts to nurse losses and eyes 109.50, while antipodeans are flat around last week’s highs amid the indecisive risk tone and weak greenback.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat as they mirrored the recent sideways price action in T-notes and with the BoJ presence in the market for JPY 1tln of JGBs counterbalanced by the lack of safe-haven demand in Japan.

PRE-MARKET CHINESE STOCK NEWS: SMI (981 HK) plans to delist from NYSE
content:
CRRC Corp (1766 HK) - US Senate introduced bill that will ban issuing DC Metro system contracts to any company owned or financially related to a nonmarket economy country. (Newswires)

Gome Electrical Appliances (493 HK) - Co. Q1 net loss CNY 86.7mln vs. Prev. profit CNY 113.3mln Y/Y, rev. CNY 17.7bln vs. Prev. CNY 17.5bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

SMI (981 HK) - Co. plans to delist New York listing. (Newswires)

Top Spring International (3688 HK) - Co. Vice Chairman Xu Lei is under disciplinary inspection in the Yunnan province. (Newswires)

Financials - CBIRC will take control of Inner Mongolia-based Baoshang Bank due to the serious credit risks it poses, in a rare takeover of a domestic

CNY - CBIRC spokesman Xiao said speculators shorting CNY will suffer heavy losses. (Newswires)

Other News - Chinese Premier Li says China will expand tax cuts to stimulate economy and that China has room to use policy tools for macro adjustments. (Newswires)

Trade

China Global Times Editor thinks a US-China trade deal will be reached but currently there are factors complicating a resolution, while the Editor also suggested US confidence in believing it can quickly press China to submit is the biggest obstacle to reaching a deal and the trade war may last for a long time. (Twitter)

Chinese envoy said there are no official talks of a meeting between US President Trump and Chinese President Xi. In related news, China State Planner VP said China's economy can remain healthy, steady and with sustainable growth despite impact from the China-US trade war. (Newswires)

US President Trump’s administration is taking steps towards issuing even more restrictions on exports of high-tech goods to China in which the Commerce Department will soon recommend rolling back regulations that made it easier for US companies to export certain goods that have both civilian and military purposes according to sources. (Politico Morning Money)
